Russian traditions are one component of Russian culture that attract visitors to Europe's largest country. Most travelers may be familiar with common Christmas and Easter traditions, but Russians don't pay homage to their pagan and Christian ancestors' way of doing things only twice a year. The Russian annual traditions calendar is full of exciting, and sometimes strange, customs, from bathing in ice water at Epiphany to Ded Moroz's appearance on New Year's Eve. 
This article deals with Russian traditions through the year. If you'd like to know when certain holidays occur, check out the Russian holidays page. Ken Scicluna/AWL Images/Getty Images Russia's New Year 
The majority of Russians celebrate New Year's Day with the rest of the world on January 1st. But an older New Year's Day tradition sees the start of the year as January 14th. Russia's New Year celebrations include the lighting of the New Year's tree and a visit from Ded Moroz, the Russian Santa . More » Russian Christmas Decoration. CC BY-NC-ND blahmni Christmas 
Christmas in Russia occurs in January. Eclipsed by New Year's celebrations, Russian Christmas is somewhat less important than it is in other Eastern European nations. Christmas is a time for visiting family, attending church services, and enjoying a Christmas feast. More » Russian Epiphany. iStockphoto/mcseem Sviatki, Russian Christmastide 
Sviatki, or Svyatki, falls between January 7th (Orthodox Christmas) and January 19th (Epiphany). Christmastide is a time for remembering old traditions, like fortune telling and carolling. The most devout end this religious period by taking a dip in the icy water of a river or stream, said to be bestowed with magical powers on Epiphany. More » Burning the Maslenitsa Effigy. CC BY-NC zigel Maslenitsa 
Maslenitsa is Russia's festive pre-Lenten custom. Children play games, mothers and grandmothers cook up big stacks of pancakes, and cities hold festivals during which the effigy of Maslenitsa herself is burnt in order to welcome springtime weather and the return of the sun. More » Russian Easter Eggs. CC BY-NC-ND Else10 Easter 
Predominately Orthodox, Russians celebrate Easter according to the Eastern calendar. The Easter church service begins the night before. Candles serve to light the church until dawn breaks, and bells announce the arrival of Easter. Easter eggs and Easter foods are an important part of Russian Easter customs. More » Eternal Flame in Moscow. CC BY-NC-SA Piero Sierra 
Victory day remembers service members and Russia's participation in WWII. This day is typically marked with parades, the military parade on Red Square being the largest and best known. More » Russian Ice Sculpture. CC by nd Sputnik Mania Russian Winter Festival 
Winter in Russia is long and hard, but Russians know how to inject fun into even sub-zero weather. It begins in December and continues into January. The winter festival isn't limited to Moscow; cities across Russia alleviate the darkness of winter by hosting winter-festival-related events. More » Samovar with Bubliki. iStockphoto/Yudina
